statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Gary Payton scored 10 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter as the Seattle SuperSonics beat the Sacramento Kings 104-92 on Wednesday night.
article.headline: Webber sidelined by latest ankle injury

images.name: Payton, Gary 011219 inline
images.caption: Gary Payton's 27 points, 10 assists and seven rebounds led Seattle.

article.linkText: With Webber out, Sonics defeat Kings
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- Gary Payton was at his best for the Seattle SuperSonics with the game on the line. Payton scored 10 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter as the SuperSonics beat the Sacramento Kings 104-92 on Wednesday night. Rashard Lewis added 20 points, Brent Barry had 19 points and nine rebounds, and Vin Baker had 16 points and nine rebounds. The victory gave the Sonics their second two-game winning streak of the season. Earlier this season, they had a three-game winning streak. "We're getting there, but we're not there yet," Payton said. "We have to understand that we have to rotate the ball better." Despite Payton's assessment, he and his teammates passed the ball well, finishing with 32 assists. Payton added 10 assists and seven rebounds in 41 minutes. He was 11-for-18 from the field, had one steal and blocked three shots. One third of the way through the season, the Sonics have beaten the four teams in the Western Conference with the best records. They also own a victory over Milwaukee, leaders of the Midwest Division in the Eastern Conference. The Kings, who led the NBA with 19 victories, were without Chris Webber. The star forward injured his left ankle Tuesday night in the win over Detroit. During the second half, Scot Pollard left with a bruised left shin and Vlade Divac sprained his right ankle. Neither player returned. Doug Christie led the Kings with 23 points, and Predgrag Stojakovic added 19 points. Kings coach Rick Adelman was disappointed with his team's performance. "Whether it's defense or rebounding, you have to play with more aggression and confidence," Adelman said. "This is the third straight road game where we didn't play with the energy we needed." The Kings got no closer than nine points during the fourth quarter. The Sonics shot 54 percent from the field and were 9-for-15 from 3-point range. "We shot the ball well and were able to get what we wanted offensively," Sonics coach Nate McMillan said. The Sonics outrebounded the Kings (47-33) and trailed only once during the game. With the Sonics controlling the backboards, the Kings were unable to get easy baskets in transition. "One of the keys was giving them only one opportunity and we did that," McMillan said. Lewis' off-balance 17 foot jumper as time expired gave the Sonics an 82-64 lead after three quarters. Up 72-63 late in the third period, the Sonics broke it open with a 6-0 run. Desmond Mason made a shot in the lane, Lewis dunked off a steal and Payton scored on a fast break for a 78-63 advantage with 1:23 left in the third quarter. The Kings had cut the deficit to 54-52 on Christie's dunk with 9:57 left in the third period. The Sonics countered with a 9-2 run. Baker started the run with a reverse layup and free throw and Payton ended its with a fast-break basket for a 63-54 lead. The Sonics were on 7-of-9 from 3-point range in the first half and shot 56 percent (22-of-39) in building a 52-46 lead.

Game notes
Payton's three blocks pushed his career total to 202. ... After scoring 19 points and pulling down 14 rebounds against Detroit on Tuesday, Chris Webber did not travel to Seattle. He twisted his ankle Tuesday against the Pistons and was held out because of left ankle tendinitis.
